result.markdown:
# Set Operations {sec-setops}

R includes set operations that can be used on vectors of any type. It does not include a
dedicated set class. The inputs to set operations should be of the same mode.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
x <- c("a", "b", "c", "d")
y <- c("c", "d", "e", "f")
```
:::


## Set Union


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
union(x, y)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] "a" "b" "c" "d" "e" "f"
```


:::
:::


## Set Intersection


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
intersect(x, y)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] "c" "d"
```


:::
:::


## Set difference

R's `setdiff()` returns the **asymmetric** set difference between two vectors.

`setdiff(x, y)` will return elements in `x` not present in `y`:


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
setdiff(x, y)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] "a" "b"
```


:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
setdiff(y, x)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] "e" "f"
```


:::
:::


## Test set equality


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
setequal(x, y)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] FALSE
```


:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
setequal(c(1, 3, 5), c(3, 5, 1))
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] TRUE
```


:::
:::


## Test if a value is element of a set


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
is.element("b", x)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] TRUE
```


:::
:::


is the same as:


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
"b" %in% x
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] TRUE
```


:::
:::
